body: @om-git216, I normally get it to work with this command `conda install -c conda-forge pytables` (the conda-forge channel may make the difference here). I hope this helps!
Thanks, I tried this, but the error still persists.
Do you restart the console after installation? Do you confirm that `tables` is present when running `conda list`?
Hi, I did restart the console after installation. Pytables version 3.6.1 is present in the conda list (not "tables" in particular).
I'm puzzled. Could you perhaps try `conda install hdf5` as well?

We've had a user reporting that `pip install tables==3.6.1` did help https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/issues/1575#issuecomment-1015275590.
I wonder if there may be tables vs pytables conflicts; I remarked that in all my (working) environments, it is tables rather than pytables that is installed.

issue.title: Problems with wxPython not allowing deeplabcut[gui] install on Windows 10

repository.name: DeepLabCut
repository.description: Official implementation of DeepLabCut: Markerless pose estimation of user-defined features with deep learning for all animals incl. humans

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Bug description

I am trying to do a new install of DLC with the GUI, and every time I try I get an error that prevents installation. Every other topic I can find where someone had this issue seems to be Linux/Ubuntu specific, but I am on Windows 10.

### Operating System

Windows 10

### DeepLabCut version

(trying to install the latest one, not successful yet)

### DeepLabCut mode

multi animal

### Device type

gpu

### Steps To Reproduce

In anaconda environment:
`pip install deeplabcut[gui]`

Everything goes smoothly until the code below.

### Anything else?

Program Versions (if this helps): 
- Python 3.9.7
- cudatoolkit 11.2.2
- cuDNN 8.1.0.77
- tensorflow 2.5.0

Troubleshooting attempts so far:
I have tried installing wxPython separately with both pip and conda install. Using conda-forge I can successfully install wxython on its own but still get the same error when attempting to pip install deeplabcut.


### Code of Conduct

- [X] I agree to follow this project's [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

issue.title: Error after saving labels

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

repository.name: DeepLabCut
repository.description: Official implementation of DeepLabCut: Markerless pose estimation of user-defined features with deep learning for all animals incl. humans

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Bug description

Hi there,

When I try to save labels I receive this error message: ImportError: Missing optional dependency 'tables'.  Use pip or conda to install tables. Which prevents me to advancing to any of the downstream steps. I've included the full log output from creating the project up until the error occurs. I've tried a number of troubleshooting solutions, but none have worked. I've include links to the proposed solutions that I've attempted in the 'Anything Else' textbox.

Thanks for your help!!
Alex

### Operating System

Windows 10

### DeepLabCut version

dlc version 2.2.0.5

### DeepLabCut mode

single animal

### Device type

NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2070 with Max-Q Design

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

### Relevant log output

```shell
(base) C:\Users\keipa>conda activate DEEPLABCUT

(DEEPLABCUT) C:\Users\keipa>ipython
Python 3.8.12 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Oct 12 2021, 21:22:46) [MSC v.1916 64 bit (AMD64)]
Type 'copyright', 'credits' or 'license' for more information
IPython 8.0.1 -- An enhanced Interactive Python. Type '?' for help.

In [1]: import deeplabcut

In [2]: deeplabcut.create_new_project(
   ...:     "TEST",
   ...:     "KEIP",
   ...:     ["D:\\Test_Video_Trimmed.M4V"],
   ...:     working_directory="C:\\Users\\keipa\\Downloads\\DeepLabCut-master\\DeepLabCut-master\\conda-environments",
   ...:     copy_videos=False,
   ...:     multianimal=False,
   ...: )

C:\Users\keipa\Downloads\DeepLabCut-master\DeepLabCut-master\conda-environments\TEST-KEIP-2022-01-21\videos\Test_Video_Trimmed.M4V

In [3]: deeplabcut.extract_frames(
   ...:     "C:\\Users\\keipa\\Downloads\\DeepLabCut-master\\DeepLabCut-master\\conda-environments\\TEST-KEIP-2022-01-21\\config.YAM
   ...: L",
   ...:     mode="automatic",
   ...:     algo="kmeans",
   ...:     userfeedback=False,
   ...:     crop=False,
   ...: )
Config file read successfully.
Extracting frames based on kmeans ...
Kmeans-quantization based extracting of frames from 0.0  seconds to 718.4  seconds.

14368it [00:23, 615.45it/s]
Kmeans clustering ... (this might take a while)

You can prevent it by setting batch_size >= 3072 or by setting the environment variable OMP_NUM_THREADS=1

You can now label the frames using the function 'label_frames' (Note, you should label frames extracted from diverse videos (and many videos; we do not recommend training on single videos!)).

   ...: L"

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

--> 311     with HDFStore(

    314         f(store)
    315 else:

File ~\anaconda3\envs\DEEPLABCUT\lib\site-packages\pandas\io\pytables.py:572, in HDFStore.__init__(self, path, mode, complevel, complib, fletcher32, **kwargs)
    569 if "format" in kwargs:
    570     raise ValueError("format is not a defined argument for HDFStore")
--> 572 tables = import_optional_dependency("tables")

    576         f"complib only supports {tables.filters.all_complibs} compression."
    577     )

File ~\anaconda3\envs\DEEPLABCUT\lib\site-packages\pandas\compat\_optional.py:118, in import_optional_dependency(name, extra, errors, min_version)
    116 except ImportError:
    117     if errors == "raise":
--> 118         raise ImportError(msg) from None
    119     else:
    120         return None

ImportError: Missing optional dependency 'tables'.  Use pip or conda to install tables.
You can now check the labels, using 'check_labels' before proceeding. Then, you can use the function 'create_training_dataset' to create the training dataset.
```


### Anything else?

https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/issues/377

https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/issues/398
